column1: The ONS said infections were "likely level" in England and Northern Ireland in the week up to 3 April
column2: but decreasing in Scotland and Wales. Overall just under 0.3% of the population - one in 350 people - tested positive.The R number for England is now estimated to be between 0.8-1.On Friday
column3: the UK reported the largest number of second vaccine doses in a single day at 449
column5: 242 first doses also administered. There were a further 3
column6: 150 confirmed cases in the past 24 hours
column7: and another 60 deaths within 28 days of a positive test.The government's scientific advisers
column9: said they were not producing a UK-wide estimate of R because of the "increasingly localised approaches" meant UK-level estimates "may not accurately reflect the current picture of the epidemic".The ONS suggests that in England
column10: about one person in 340 tested positive in the week to 3 April. In Northern Ireland
column12: in Scotland one in 410 and in Wales one in 800. Across the UK as a whole
column13: the study suggests that levels are similar to those seen in late September last year. Find out how the pandemic has affected your area and how it compares with the national average: If you can't see the look-up click here.
